Warning (2016-10-12): There seems to be a bug in the EA that may stop it from working properly. It is strongly recommended not to use this EA on live accounts until further notice.

This trading system is based on a set of different trade logic for the first trade. If the market goes against our favorite direction, every N pips we open another position according to Martingale strategy. If the net profit reaches to what we set in the input settings of the EA, all the open positions will be closed.  
  
The entry logic is **Trade Bollinger Bands,** where A position will be opened when the candle is closed above/below BB bands.  
  
**Exponential Basket Close:**  
If the user set the input parameter "**Exponential Basket Close?** " to "**Yes** ", then the EA closes all the open position at a lower target profit as an exponential function of the number of open positions. For example, if there are 7 open positions, and the take profit is set to 20.0 USD, then the EA will close all the seven positions if their net profit reach at a lower profit than 20.0 (let's say 3.0 USD). This option is there to test the idea of getting out of a sequence of losers with some smaller profit as soon as possible (that is, before blowing up the account).  
  
**NOTE 1: Martingale based EAs are very risky! Use this EA at your own risk. There is no guarantee that the EA will be profitable or bug-free.**  
**NOTE 2: This EA works on any time frame.**  
  
**\--- Update 2016-09-29---**  
**Version 2.00** of the EA released.

1\. What does it mean by grid size? How many pips price must move for next order to open.  
  
2\. as default, TP is set 1. Does it mean 1% target or else? When all open trades reach a equity profit of 1.00 all trades close.  
  
3\. what is the multiply of martiangle if the price goes against the direction? Doubles lot size per each new order.  
  
And what is the pip step (N pips) for the next open position in marti? Pip step (N pip) is the grid size, is set at 10 pips in the EA.  
  
I did not write the EA but from the tests I ran, those are your answers.  
  
In 6 month back test I did on this EA it will blow a few accounts depending on the pair. Others do fairly well with minimal DD. So its hit or miss. Not something you would even consider throwing live. At least not the way its currently configured.

MathTrader7:  
The EA is looking good. Please consider adding one input that controls Candle Range.  
  
For example:  
If(CandleRange>60) StopTrading=true;  
The EA would sttop trading and allow the current trades to close at 0 profit, or the user can close them  
The EA would reactivate either manually (user restarting EA) or when the start time comes up.  
  
I have found this to be useful for when price starts to become volatile. So far I have seen this work on the lower TFs.  
It has not failed to stop the EA from trading when the pair is ranging crazy and thereby avoid the potential loss.  
  
No hurry, whenever you can get around to it is fine.  
Take care and thank you for your coding effort  
Jess

FXCyborg:  
The candle range refers to size of the current candle. I have found that when you are trading as long as the candles sizes or price movements are relatively stable that is little volatility, that you can trade thru it successfully. However, then there comes that moment that all hell breaks loose and price goes all over the place like crazy and forms huge candles. So what is the best thing to do? STOP TRADING and wait for the mess to calm down. You do this by monitoring the current size of the candle and if it is larger than what you expect, you stop the EA from trading immediately and start to close trades for 0$ or small loss. In my case I have seen on EURUSD on the 15min that 60 pips is a considerable size.  
  
It's a simple observation...  
  
Jess

AUD/CHF, CAD/CHF, NZD/CAD, NZD/CHF also test pretty well with this EA. Like someone said earlier, the more range the better. Increasing the grid size and lowering the marti muliplier to 1.25-1.50 also helps reduce the drawdown. Reduces the profits a bit also, but you can withstand more levels. **Version 1.45** of the EA released. In this version the **user can select the entry logic** from four different types:

  1. **Follow Previous Candle**. A position will be opened in the direction of the previous candle.
  2. **Trade Bollinger Bands**. A position will be opened when the candle is closed above/below BB bands.
  3. **Trade Reverse Candle**. A position will be opened when the last candle is closed in the opposite direction of its previous candle.
  4. **Pattern Type I**. A position will be opened when a valid Japanese candle stick pattern is formed.

I updated [Post 1](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=598198). 

Trading is the hardest way to make easy money...

Well, I am not so sure about the "incredible" part.  
  
Deposit: $100  
Max. DD: -$273  
  
In other words: **the DD is 2.7x larger than the deposit...**  
  
The crash was avoided simply because this large DD happened in the later part of the backtest (around trade #205 which was sometime in 2015) when the accumulated profits allowed such a big DD.  
  
So if the backtest had been started in 2015 the P&L graph would have ended in a vertical line.  
  
Conclusion: the absolute max. DD should be always related to the initial deposit (in %) when fixed lots are used as this number is NOT shown on the backtest reports.

From the testing I have done on this, I can give you a general overview of the setting.   
  
More profit and more risk: Small grid size (Under 50 pips), small time frame (less than H1), larger TP , larger multipler (1.7 or higher)  
  
Less profit and less risk: larger grid size (over 50 pips), longer time frame (H1-D1), Smaller TP, smaller multipler (1.1-1.5)  
  
Takes about 10 minutes to test a years worth of data so run a bunch and you will get the feel for what each setting does. I prefer the smaller multipliers (1.1-1.3) and H! time frame.. Much less draw down. Less profit also but some times not all that much less. Keep in mind too that seeing 25% drawdown on the tester might not look that bad. But if you were trading live you would feel much different about that.

**\- don't trade under 45 Pips (450) with EURUSD prefer 55 Pips (550)**  
  
**\- trade only EURUSD or EURCHF or USDCHF**  
  
**\- don't trade other pairs is dangerous**  
  
**\- I'm a expert of Martingale EA**

I have tested your ea and I now run it on a demo account. Personally I'm looking for a setup where you can start with a low balance (maximum 1000 ) and manage to make 3-5 times the initial deposit and withdraw before the ea lose all money, then deposit another 1000 again and start over. ( I have succesfully used martingale system like this before )  
  
I have a few recommendations for next version, based on the moments I saw the EA is ussually losing all balance:  
\- first of all I have found 5 min charts to work much better than 1H. If you use control points for testing you will be very far from real market conditions while testing  
\- you should introduce more working hours options for the EA. In all testes I got better returns and lower DD at night, avoiding the high volatility during news release. But now I can set working hours lets say from 0 to 10.00 but can't restart it same day let's say from 18.00 to 23.59 after most euro news are gone  
\- When EA is paused because of working hours settings it should close all positions no matter if they are winning or losing  
\- when you setup a maximum number of opened positions sometimes the ea will close all positions on loss. Somehow it does not calculcate the overall P/L right.  
\- you should remove the limitation of 1 to 2 martingale ( for example I have succesfully used a system with x3 lot multiplier )

This is not find a perfect entry EA. Its more of a grid/recovery EA. Any indicators are only good for the first entry any way. Adding more will only pollute the thread, cause Math aggravation and confuse the crap out of everyone else. Ill second the thought of less is better.   
  
Entry does not really matter from BT's I have done. Sometimes follow last candle performed best, sometimes MA was best. All depends on when you started the test and how long it ran. If you forward test it would be the same. There are 4 settings to really concern yourself with: Grid size/Net TP value/mart. multiplier/time frame. How you configure those 4 will determine if you make it or break it. The rest is just window dressing. I have not tested BE yet so cant comment on that one. My guess is it might save some DD but decrease profit.

Hi All!   
  
I know there are many M threads around and Ive been sticked in for few years in them since Martingale arrive.. I have lost a lot with it. Not only money..  
  
I really appreciate the progress it makes in years. Mathtrader does fantastic work here. Im pretty sure that most of you knows exactly whats going on by Martingale. However I need to copy a conclusion of nick named Gary for every newbie here. Those few sentences convinced me to stop waste my time with Martingale. Having said that let to be known that there are fundmanagers and big players who use M in some scenarios.   
  
  
  
There are a zillion ways you could play the numbers, Let us know if you find a miracle Martingale. From my experiments, my conclusions are:

  1. A Martingale will not turn a losing system into a winner, unless you NEVER hit the blow-up case. In a normal situation where you occasionally hit the bail-out level, the Martingale usually loses significantly worse than the basic non-M system.
  2. If the system is a random coin-flip, the Martingale results will also be random. Sometimes better, sometimes worse.
  3. If the system is a winner, a Martingale will increase the profits, but you have all the Martingale problems. You can achieve similar returns just by increasing your position size, and you will have fixed known risks, a more consistent and sane equity curve, and no worry of a Martingale blowup.
  4. If you have a high-win% system, your chances of long strings of losses are reduced (but NOT eliminated). E.g. for a system that wins 70% of its trades, the chance of N consecutive losses is (1-70%)^N; the chance of 7 consecutive losses is 0.30^7 = 0.022%. If you can survive 6 consecutive losses, you have only 1 chance in 4500 of blowing up with 7 losses. But remember those 21 consecutive losses with 50% wins... If you never blow up, your closed-equity curve is a beautiful straight line. But once again with that 70% system you could get about the same results just by increasing your position size by about 1.7x, and you have none of the Martingale risks.
  5. Bailing after a few consecutive losses results in smaller blowup losses, but the blowups happen more often. Bailing after more consecutive losses causes fewer blowup losses, but they're bigger. The end result tends to be similar even though the equity curves may look very different.
  6. If you're lucky, you won't hit many blowups, and you'll make more money than without the Martingale. If you're NOT lucky, you may hit a lot of blowups, and you'll lose far more than you would have without the Martingale. If you're like me, the Trading Gods will guarantee you see the latter result, and the Martingale will kill you.

Therefore: I conclude that Martingale Mania is a will-o-the-wisp, a fantasy. Martingales hugely increase your risks without providing any benefit. Martingales won't help you unless your system is already a winner, and if your system is a winner, a Martingale is a bad way to increase its returns.  
  
Just Say No to Martingales."

Hi blade813,  
  
1\. Anti-martingale (or reverse Martingale) is a strategy to add to winners (unlike add to losers strategy of Martingale). When you enable this input setting, then after the first position is opened, if price goes in the profit zone, the EA will open additional positions with the same lot sequencing (and grid size) and at the same time of opening a new additional position, it adjusts the stop losses such that if price reverses and hits the stop losses, the overall profit of the positions will be positive.  
  
2\. If you change the time frame, then depending on what trade logic has been set in the input settings, the EA applies that logic on the new time frame while it keeps track of the previously opened positions on H1 chart.  
  
Best,  
Math

just an observation after reading through this thread -- not intended for anyone in particular  
  
it seems many want to jump on the "martingdale will blow your account" bandwagon here. while I do agree that a true strategy like that could indeed blow your account, so will many other kinds of bad trading strategies. if you don't use good money management, and don't have some sort of viable strategy, you probably will eventually lose all of your money, no matter how you trade.  
  
so rather looking at this as a true "martingdale" strategy, think of it as a multiple entry strategy which many successful traders use. I traded with Boris Schlossberg's group for awhile and the foundation of the strategy was taking multiple entries if price moved against you. There are many variations used by many traders. Some using only 2 or 3 levels, some using 6 or 7. Its all about money management. You use the available settings to determine how many levels you want to go, how much of your capital you want to risk, ect.  
  
MathTrader has created an EA that allows you to customize the strategy to your own liking. He's not selling it. He's not asking you to subscribe for a fee. He's taking his own time and experimenting with many scenarios to see what works best. Rather than question the back testing results, put the EA on a demo account and test it. Pretend its your real money and trade it how you would if it was real. Experiment with different settings, different pairs, different time frames, ect. If there is a bug, point it out. If your settings/pairs aren't successful, point it out. if you think a new feature will improve the EA, make a suggestion. We can all learn from each other. If you think this strategy is a waste of time or too risky for your liking, move along to a new thread.  
  
I started testing this myself a little over a week ago. the demo account i'm using is up over 15%, trading mostly low volatility pairs that tend to range during the day. these are the perfect pairs for this strategy. they typically move up and down in a fairly tight range. can they take off in one direction at any time? of course. money management.   
  
don't be greedy. if your first position is down 20 pips, and you open a 2nd position that moves 20 pips, your first position is breakeven and 2nd is +20 . take the money and run, start again. may not seem like a lot, but doing it over and over will add up. be smart when you trade. obviously you don't want to be in front of major news, central bank statements, ect. let the market calm down, then take advantage of the range.  
  
special thanks to MathTrader for the time put into the EA and answering questions. also thanks to those who have made great suggestions that have found their way into the EA. keep positive and help each other. good luck to all  
  
blade

Hi Blade, I agree with you.  
  
I think that trading with this kind of strategies implies 2 questions:  
  
\- the level of drawdown a trader can sustain (for instance let's say 20% drawdown?)  
\- the time you need to recover this drawdown with the profit you have for every cycle.  
  
Let's say I've been hit with a 20% drawdown on a cycle. If the strategy usually gives me a 0.5% daily gain (remember, don't be greedy).  
  
I will need around 2 months to recover the drawdown and return to the equity peak.  
  
I can reduce the available max drawdown, but I will obviously obtain an higher amount of stops hitted.  
  
To me, it's all to find the right balance with max drawdown and daily profit.

First I want to say thanks to MathTrader7 for his great work ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)  
  
Here is, how I use and try the EA at the moment (I know not everybody ist fan of martingale): I initialised a demo account with 100 EUR, installed the EA on three pairs and let them run the whole day. At night I withdraw all the money above 100.- EUR, so that my accounts starts the next day again with 100.- EUR. Of course I also risk a complete loss of my account during the day.   
  
Here are the results:  
1\. day: 33.- EUR withdrawn  
2\. day: 31.- EUR   
3\. day: 21.- EUR  
4\. day: 41.- EUR  
5\. day: 16.- EUR  
today: 16.- EUR (until now)  
(in sum 158.- EUR withdrawn in six days)  
  
So, my maximum risk is 100.- EUR (the day) and the average profit per day is up to now 26.- EUR.  
The success for this account management depends on how often the EA will blow up the account. We will see.  
  
Next week I decided to spend 100.- EUR in a real account and look what happened. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Nice weekend to all   
Siero

Thanks for asking this question, I forgot to explain it in the first post.  
  
If the user set the input parameter "**Exponential Basket Close?** " to "**Yes** ", then the EA closes all the open position at a lower target profit as an exponential function of the number of open positions. For example, if there are 7 open positions, and the take profit is set to 20.0 USD, then the EA will close all the seven positions if their net profit reach at a lower profit than 20.0 (let's say 3.0 USD). This option is there to test the idea of getting out of a sequence of losers with some smaller profit as soon as possible (that is, before blowing up the account). 

Trading is the hardest way to make easy money...

Hello xmess7,  
  
Please note that **End Hour** must be **LOWER** than **Start Hour** , other wise the EA won't take any trade.  
  
For example, if you want to set the EA to work **from 19:00 to 06:00 in your broker's time** , you have to enable both time filters as below:  
  
Use Time Filter 1? **Yes**  
Start 1 Hour (0-23) = **19**  
Start 1 Minute (0-59) = **0**  
End 1 Hour (0-23) = **23**  
End 1 Minute (0-59) = **59**  
Use Time Filter 2? **Yes**  
Start 2 Hour (0-23) = **0**  
Start 2 Minute (0-59) = **0**  
End 2 Hour (0-23) = **6**  
End 2 Minute (0-59) = **0**  
  
Best,

HI xmess7,  
  
If it happened in the backtest, then I guess you have set the mode to Control Points.  
If it happened in live/demo forward test, then there must be a quick jump of price after the EA calculated the net profit to be greater than zero. There is no way to completely avoid this problem if price changes against our favorite direction at the time of closing the basket of orders.  
  
Best,

Hello,  
  
First of all, thanks to MathTrader7. I've been following this thread while learning how to code for cAlgo, so here is the code for the cBot version of this EA. I have no intention of keep working on this cBot so I'm publishing the code for anyone to work on it.  
  
Features  
-MA Entry  
-Dynamic Grid  
-Trade Hours (ghostbiker trading hours)  
-Minimum margin level stop  
  

Inserted Code
    
    
    // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    //
    //  Martingale
    //  *MA Cross
    //  Dynamic Grid
    //  by: Protito 11/September/2016
    // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    using System;
    using System.Linq;
    using cAlgo.API;
    using cAlgo.API.Indicators;
    using cAlgo.API.Internals;
    using cAlgo.Indicators;
    namespace cAlgo
    {
        [Robot(TimeZone = TimeZones.UTC, AccessRights = AccessRights.None)]
        public class MartingaleBot : Robot
        {
            [Parameter("MA Type")]
            public MovingAverageType MAType { get; set; }
            [Parameter()]
            public DataSeries SourceSeries { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Slow Periods", DefaultValue = 10)]
            public int slowPeriods { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Fast Periods", DefaultValue = 5)]
            public int fastPeriods { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Martingale Factor", DefaultValue = 1.5)]
            public double mgFactor { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Min. Grid size", DefaultValue = 150)]
            public int minGridSize { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Periods Grid", DefaultValue = 30)]
            public int gridPeriod { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Initial Lot Size", DefaultValue = 0.02)]
            public double iniLotSize { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Target Profit (money)", DefaultValue = 3.0)]
            public double targetProfit { get; set; }
            [Parameter("Min. Margin Level(%)", DefaultValue = 100)]
            public double minMarginLevel { get; set; }
     
            private MovingAverage slowMa;
            private MovingAverage fastMa;
            private RelativeStrengthIndex rsi;
            bool buyTradeActive = false;
            bool sellTradeActive = false;
            TradeType tradeType = TradeType.Buy;
            double currentGridSize = 0;
            int mgLevel = 1;
            Position basePosition = null;
            double currentMgVolume;
            long currentMgVolumeInt;
            bool invertedBuy = false;
            bool invertedSell = false;
            protected override void OnStart()
            {
                currentMgVolume = iniLotSize * 100000;
                currentMgVolumeInt = Convert.ToInt64(currentMgVolume);
                fastMa = Indicators.MovingAverage(SourceSeries, fastPeriods, MAType);
                slowMa = Indicators.MovingAverage(SourceSeries, slowPeriods, MAType);
                rsi = Indicators.RelativeStrengthIndex(SourceSeries, 9);
                currentGridSize = minGridSize;
                if (Init("Sell"))
                {
                    sellTradeActive = true;
                    tradeType = TradeType.Buy;
                }
                if (Init("Buy"))
                {
                    buyTradeActive = true;
                    tradeType = TradeType.Sell;
                }
            }
            private bool Init(string tradeTypeString)
            {
                if (Positions.Find("MGBase" + tradeTypeString + Symbol.Code) != null)
                {
                    basePosition = Positions.Find("MGBase" + tradeTypeString + Symbol.Code);
                    foreach (Position p in Positions.FindAll("MG" + tradeTypeString + Symbol.Code))
                    {
                        mgLevel++;
                        currentMgVolume *= mgFactor;
                    }
                    return true;
                }
                return false;
            }
            protected override void OnTick()
            {
                if (buyTradeActive || sellTradeActive)
                {
                    AdjustGrid();
                    CheckProfit();
                    TickOperation();
                }
            }
            protected override void OnBar()
            {
                if (buyTradeActive || sellTradeActive)
                {
                    return;
                }
                var currentSlowMa = slowMa.Result.Last(0);
                var currentFastMa = fastMa.Result.Last(0);
                var previousSlowMa = slowMa.Result.Last(1);
                var previousFastMa = fastMa.Result.Last(1);
                bool rsiBuy = rsi.Result.IsRising();
                bool rsiSell = rsi.Result.IsFalling();
                //Buy signal
                if (previousSlowMa > previousFastMa && currentSlowMa <= currentFastMa && rsiBuy)
                {
                    if (OpenPosition("Buy"))
                        buyTradeActive = true;
                }
                //Sell signal
                else if (previousSlowMa < previousFastMa && currentSlowMa >= currentFastMa && rsiSell)
                {
                    if (OpenPosition("Sell"))
                        sellTradeActive = true;
                }
            }
            private void AdjustGrid()
            {
                double low = MarketSeries.Low.Minimum(gridPeriod);
                double high = MarketSeries.High.Maximum(gridPeriod);
                double distance = high - low;
                double distancePips = distance / Symbol.PipSize;
                double newGrid = distancePips * 10 * 0.23;
                if (newGrid < minGridSize)
                    currentGridSize = minGridSize;
                else
                    currentGridSize = newGrid;
            }
            private bool OpenPosition(string tradeTypeString)
            {
                tradeType = TradeType.Buy;
                if (tradeTypeString == "Sell")
                    tradeType = TradeType.Sell;
                var result = ExecuteMarketOrder(tradeType, Symbol, currentMgVolumeInt, "MGBase" + tradeTypeString + Symbol.Code);
                if (!result.IsSuccessful)
                {
                    return false;
                }
                basePosition = result.Position;
                Print(tradeTypeString + " BASE Position open at: " + basePosition.EntryPrice);
                return true;
            }
            private void TickOperation()
            {
                if (!WorkingHours())
                    return;
                string tradeTypeString = "";
                if (Symbol.Ask < basePosition.EntryPrice - mgLevel * currentGridSize * Symbol.PipSize / 10 && buyTradeActive)
                {
                    tradeTypeString = "Buy";
                }
                else if (Symbol.Bid > basePosition.EntryPrice + mgLevel * currentGridSize * Symbol.PipSize / 10 && sellTradeActive)
                {
                    tradeTypeString = "Sell";
                }
                else
                    return;
                mgLevel++;
                currentMgVolume *= mgFactor;
                currentMgVolumeInt = Convert.ToInt64(currentMgVolume) / 1000 * 1000;
                var result = ExecuteMarketOrder(tradeType, Symbol, currentMgVolumeInt, "MG" + tradeTypeString + Symbol.Code);
                if (!result.IsSuccessful)
                {
                    mgLevel--;
                    currentMgVolume /= mgFactor;
                    return;
                }
                Print(tradeTypeString + " Position open at " + result.Position.EntryPrice + " Volume(double): " + currentMgVolume + " GridSize: " + currentGridSize);
            }
            private bool WorkingHours()
            {
                //return true;
                var currentHour = Server.Time.TimeOfDay.TotalHours;
                if (currentHour > 1.25 && currentHour < 5.75)
                    return true;
                if (currentHour > 7.25 && currentHour < 17.25)
                    return true;
                return false;
            }
            private bool CheckProfit()
            {
                string tradeTypeString = "Buy";
                if (sellTradeActive)
                    tradeTypeString = "Sell";
                double profit = 0;
                profit += basePosition.NetProfit;
                foreach (Position p in Positions.FindAll("MGBuy" + Symbol.Code))
                {
                    profit += p.NetProfit;
                }
                foreach (Position p in Positions.FindAll("MGSell" + Symbol.Code))
                {
                    profit += p.NetProfit;
                }
                if (profit >= targetProfit)
                {
                    CloseAll();
                }
                Colors labelColor = Colors.LightGreen;
                if (Account.MarginLevel < minMarginLevel)
                {
                    CloseAll();
                }
                if (profit < 0)
                    labelColor = Colors.LightSalmon;
                string labelText = "## MG " + tradeTypeString + " Order ##";
                labelText += "\nDepth:\t" + mgLevel;
                labelText += "\nProfit:\t " + profit;
                labelText += "\nGrid:\t" + currentGridSize;
                ChartObjects.DrawText("Label1", labelText, StaticPosition.TopLeft, labelColor);
                //Print("Profit: " + profit);
                return false;
            }
            private void CloseAll()
            {
                Print("-- Closed All");
                foreach (Position p in Positions.FindAll("MGSell" + Symbol.Code))
                {
                    ClosePositionAsync(p);
                }
                foreach (Position p in Positions.FindAll("MGBuy" + Symbol.Code))
                {
                    ClosePositionAsync(p);
                }
                ClosePositionAsync(basePosition);
                buyTradeActive = false;
                sellTradeActive = false;
                mgLevel = 1;
                currentMgVolume = iniLotSize * 100000;
                currentMgVolumeInt = Convert.ToInt64(currentMgVolume);
            }
        }
    }

Hi traders,  
  
I have been testing this method for the last three weeks in demo accounts. And I have experienced that the Martingala can blow up your account if the trend goes agains you enough time/pips (nothing new that we didn't know before).  
  
I realized that a long trend with too small retracement can kill your account, because the martingala will open the same kind of order following the grid. In the picture below you will see the martingala opening 8 orders. Luckily the price went short before opening the 9th order, because the input Max Martingala was 8 for me. So, just few more pips and the account would have been seriously damanaged.  
  
In order to avoid long trends killing my account, I thought of a possible solution: I would like to decide the kind of order that the martingala opens for every grid level. For example:  
\- 1) The EA opens a SELL order.  
\- 2) The price goes up and reaches the first grid: The martingala opens an order with double lots following the trend: BUY, instead of a second SELL.  
\- 3) If the price continues up, the EA takes the benefit and closes both. If the price goes down: The martingala opens a SELL order with triple lots.  
  
By this way, even if we have many orders opened we would protect our DD by having a lot of floating positive and negative orders, not just negative order accumulating loses as in the tradicional martingala.  
  
Another option is to tell the martingala to open the orders randomly for every grid level, or maybe open the orders following the previous candle colour...  
  
What do you think of this modification? Is it possible to implement? Do you think it would reduce the DD as intended?  
  
Thanks for your attention.  
  
/Regards

It will work ok as long as price does not bounce up and down in a range for extended time. Eventually you will need price to break out far enough to take a profit. If you are going to double the lot size on each order, your margin will be eaten up if the price sits in a range too long. Its also very easy to hit your max martingale of 8 doing it this way. Granted since you will be partially hedged your loss wont be as bad. So just like you cant handle steep trend with this EA, doing it your way you cant handle an extended ranging period. There is always a trade off, no magic bullets in forex.

See if you find the following code useful, I wrote it for my own EAs - it calculates breakeven price and profit/pips totals for a series of open Buy or Sell orders  
Note that the last 4 variables passed by reference  
  

Inserted Code
    
    
    //+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
    //| ********** f_Point() **********
    //|
    //| Returns correct Point multiplier depending on Broker Digits
    //+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
    double f_Point()
      {
       if(Point==0.00001) return 0.0001;
       else if(Point==0.001) return 0.01;
       else return Point;
      }
    //+------------------------------------------------------------------+
    //| fm_ScanTicketRange()
    //+------------------------------------------------------------------+
    void fm_ScanTicketRange(int _magic,
                            int _ticket1,
                            int _ticket2,
                            int _order_type,
                            double &_total_lots,
                            double &_total_pips,
                            double &_total_profit,
                            double &_breakeven_price)
      {
       _total_lots=0;
       _total_pips=0;
       _total_profit=0;
       _breakeven_price=0;
       if(_ticket1==0 || _ticket2==0 || _order_type<OP_BUY || _order_type>OP_SELL) return;
    //--- First Pass (calculate lot size total for all open orders)
       for(int _apos1=0;_apos1<OrdersTotal();_apos1++)
         {
          if(OrderSelect(_apos1,SELECT_BY_POS,MODE_TRADES)==true)
            {
             if(OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber()==_magic && OrderType()==_order_type && OrderTicket()>=_ticket1 && OrderTicket()<=_ticket2)
                _total_lots=_total_lots+OrderLots();
            }
         }
    //--- Second Pass
       for(int _apos2=0;_apos2<OrdersTotal();_apos2++)
         {
          if(OrderSelect(_apos2,SELECT_BY_POS,MODE_TRADES)==true)
            {
             if(OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber()==_magic && OrderType()==_order_type && OrderTicket()>=_ticket1 && OrderTicket()<=_ticket2)
               {
                _total_profit=_total_profit+OrderProfit()+OrderSwap()+OrderCommission();
                if(_total_lots>0) _breakeven_price=_breakeven_price+((OrderLots()/_total_lots)*OrderOpenPrice());
                if(OrderType()==OP_BUY) _total_pips=_total_pips+((OrderClosePrice()-OrderOpenPrice())/f_Point());
                else if(OrderType()==OP_SELL) _total_pips=_total_pips+((OrderOpenPrice()-OrderClosePrice())/f_Point());
               }
            }
         }
       _total_lots=NormalizeDouble(_total_lots,2);
       _total_pips=NormalizeDouble(_total_pips,1);
       _total_profit=NormalizeDouble(_total_profit,2);
       _breakeven_price=NormalizeDouble(_breakeven_price,Digits);
       return;
      }

Hi again,  
  
I am just trying to write down some more thought that potentially might help in the development of this EA or they could be totally wrong. Please help me to evaluate.  
I would like to compare two possibilities for opening orders:  
1) Opening new orders, always in the same direction (like now)  
2) Opening new orders following the trend that touched the grid and make us open a new order.   
I have made a small summary of what would happen if the market goes against us all the time (worst situation). In the first case the worst situation is a long trend without retracements, and in the second case the worst case is a ranging market.  
  
Look at the picture below for the following examples:  
In Case 1: after 8 martingala orders we have 0.2 lots in BUY direction.  
In case 2: after 17 martingala orders we have 0.2 lots in BUY direction. (There are more lots opened, but they are hedging)  
  
In Case 1; after 3 martingala orders we have 0,04 lots opened in BUY direction.  
In case 2; after 10 martingala orders we have 0,04 lots opened in BUY direction.  
  
If we consider Forex a theoretical random market, we will obviously reach Martingala levels 17 and 10 fewer times than Martingala levels 8 and 3. Thus, it is much safer to open the orders adapting to the trend.  
  
@MathTrader7. I think it is worth to give it a try and test this new concept. Would it be possible to have an option in the EA to choose how we want the martingala to open the orders? First option) Orders opened always in the same direction (like now). Second option) Following the trend that made the martingala open a new order. (Like explained above)

Hi,  
  
Another example of how benefitial would be opening the orders according to the trend, and not waiting for the price to reverse (like now).  
  
In the chart below the winning trade is Long 18 (Instead of double the minilots I used another hedge: 1,2,3,5,7,12,18)  
  
The winning trade will have a total of 29 minilots (Long 1 + Long 3 + Long 7 + Long 18), and a total winning of 29 x 20 pips = 580 pips.  
The lossing trades will have a total of 19 minilots (Short 2 + Short 5 + Short 12), and a total lossing of 19 x 30 = 570 pips.  
Net gain: 10 pips.  
  
If price exits the trend, we take gains inmediatly.  
If price ranges between two grid levels, the negative equity of losing contracts is offset by the opposite hedge. The dradown is very well contained as I represented in the table of my previous post.  
  
This is definitely a more conservative martingale that will help us **containing the DD**.  
  
@MathTrader7, do you think is possible to add this option is the next version of the EA? I think we need to have an intrument to contain the DD in the EA, and this could be a solution.  
  
Thanks all for your kind support,  
Regards

Hi,  
  
I have prepared an excel file that calculates how many orders our martingale EA supports before blowing up the account. It is very useful to determine the parameter Max Marti.  
The input parameters that you need to provide (Upper left corner in the Excel sheet)  
\- Balance  
\- Number of pairs you are trading  
\- Grid size  
\- Martingale multiplier  
  
The excel file will paint in green how many orders you can support with those inputs. Just change them and optimize your parameter!  
(Take into account that it is based in an initial 0.1 lot. And also that the sheet will considered the worst case: All the pairs are going into the _Max Marti_ at the same time. To change it, just write less "_Number of pairs you are trading_ ")  
  
By the way, in paralel you will see the number of orders supported by the Martingale, but for the case of using a contained DD martingale.  
  
Example:  
Initial Balance: 1.000  
Number of pair trading: 4  
Grid size: 20 (200 points)  
Martingala Mult: 1.5  
  
Result:  
Maximum number of Martingales: 6  
Maximum number of Contained DD Martingales: 12  
  
Hope you find it useful, and please consider implementing the option "Contained DD Martingale" in coming versions of the EA. It will reduce the risk of reaching Max Martin to less than half.  
  
Thanks for your attention.  
Regards

Hi MathTrader7,  
  
Attached you can find "Study Martingale v2". I have fixed a bug in the code, and added an extra feature.  
You should now also indicate what is your maximum Leverage.  
The Excel sheet will paint in green next to the Contained DD Martingale what is the maximum level you can reach according to your Leverage and balance.  
The amount of Lots that you can play is normally more restrictive than your equity for the "DD Conservative Martingale". In case of the regular Martingale, it's the equity that usually kills your account.  
  
**Example:**  
Initial balance: 500  
Number of pairs (considered for the worst case):2  
Grid size: 150 points (15 pips)  
Martingala Mult: 1,25  
Max Leverage: 400  
  
**Result:**  
\- With the regular Martingale we can reach a maximum of 9 levels.  
\- With the "DD conservative Martingale" we reach: Vertical limit (amount of lots): 19 levels. Horizontal limit (maximim cost/order): 30. So, we reach 19.  
  
That means that _using the DD Conservative Martingale we reach 19 levels, with the regular Martingale 9 levels_. Huge difference.  
  
  
@MathTrader7,  
I think it's worth to try it. Do you think you can implement the _DD Conservative Martingale_ as an option it in the next version of the EA?  
  
Thanks,  
Regards

For those looking to add ADR to their code, here is something I picked up on MQL5 forums - seems to be working correctly  
  
Just include the function in your EA and do the calculation inside  
  

Inserted Code
    
    
    double AverageRange(int TF,int length)
      {
       double sum=0;
       int nBars=iBars(p_Symbol,TF);
       int iLimit=length;
       if(iLimit>nBars) iLimit=nBars;
       for(int iPos=0; iPos<iLimit; iPos++)
         {
          double H=iHigh(p_Symbol,TF,iPos);
          double L=iLow(p_Symbol,TF,iPos);
          sum+=H-L;
         }
       return(NormalizeDouble((sum)/iLimit,1));
      }

  
Sample of average calculation:  
  

Inserted Code
    
    
    double d_Avg_ADR=(AverageRange(PERIOD_D1,3)+AverageRange(PERIOD_H4,3)+AverageRange(PERIOD_H1,3))/3;

I am using 1010 also. Sometimes where you think the files are located are not the exact location .. try this:  
  
Go to top of MT4 and in the menu items, go to File --> Open Data Folder  
  
From there you should see folders, go into MQL4 folder and then Experts .. drop the EA there.  
  
After that, go back into MT4, right click on Expert Advisors in Navigator Window and hit Refresh .. you should now see the EA   
  
Hope this helps

ahmadalbab1:  
Hi, in the OPTIONS-->Expert Advisors uncheck the following:  
Disable automated trading when the account has been changed  
Disable automated trading when the profile has changed  
  
What those do is turn off the EA if u make any change to your charts where the EA is located.  
If I remember, even if u change timeframes or inputs that will cause the EA to stop trading with these two options activated.  
So uncheck them, that way at least they won't be a factor that stops your EA from trading.

E.g. EURUSD:  
Annual profit: +130%  
CAGR %/year: +130% (Compounded Annual Growth Rate)  
MDD %: -61% (Note: The MDD calculated on the % drawdown compared to initial deposit)

Profit Factor: 2.04

Mini lot = All currency.  
Example,  
If you have MM about 500, you should setup EA initial lot = 0.01.  
If you have MM about 1,000, you should setup EA initial lot = 0.02  
If you have MM about 1,500, you should setup EA initial lot = 0.03  
If you have MM about 2,000, you should setup EA initial lot = 0.04  
If you have MM about 2,500, you should setup EA initial lot = 0.05  
.

n  
  
So that, minimum MM 500 per 0.01 lot.

@_[xinix1974](http://www.forexfactory.com/xinix1974)_ @[_bkproteus_](http://www.forexfactory.com/bkproteus)  
I'll enable EA to Long and Short and wait for last all order closed by EA or current my positions have the net profit, I'll close all order suddenly.  
And then I'll disable all EA after that, I' ll setup EA to Only Long or Only Short for switch direction to follows the trend again.  
Although positions are still open and the direction is changed, but last your positions to recovery and close by EA, if MM is enough and not over trade.  
MM is very important.  
  
[_@bkproteus_](http://www.forexfactory.com/bkproteus)  
You can setup clock alarm to alert hourly on Mobile/Watch/Clock on the desk for signal close to the candle by H1.  
(I'm going to find Trend Magic indicator for mobile alert.)  
If you want to rest, you should disable EA before another work.

TP in **Money** , EA count TP as your deposit currency.  
If TP in **pip** or **point** , you can set initial lot 0.1.  
e.g.  
If TP in **Pip** , you can set TP=**30** , initial lot 0.1. when you get TP >> (30x10)x0.1 = 30 USD.  
If TP in **Point** , you can set TP=**300** , initial lot 0.1. when you get TP >> 300x0.1 = 30 USD.

**DEFINITION of 'Fat Finger Error'**  
A human error caused by pressing the wrong key when using a computer to input data. Fat finger errors are often harmless but can sometimes have significant consequences for example, if the wrong number is entered in performing a mathematical calculation.

Dont think of it as "martingale" .. think of it as a multiple entry strategy and keep in mind ..  
  
1\. You can control which pairs and how many to trade  
2\. You can control your position sizes  
3\. You can control whether you only buy or only sell based on a trend  
4\. You can control how many levels you want to enter and distance of the levels  
5\. You can control how much in currency you are willing to risk on each trade  
  
As Tony and Ghost have shown, this EA can be quite profitable, just have to be smart to increase the chances of being successful.

Hi folks.  
  
The following is info so that many of you can understand what the error entails and the possible solution. This is not a request for source cide but if math ever decides it would be of great benefit.  
  
First off and array is a container that holds items. Think of it as a list. The list has a definite number. So in the case the program was trying to read an item that was not in the list, in fact it wenr beyond the number of items. Say the list is 10 items, the program tried to read item 11 which dies not exist and is beyond the list.  
  
So the solution is to either extend the array (add an item) or make the program not look for an item that is beyind the range. Of course there could be other things that haooend before that affect the size of the array too, so we got to look at those too.  
The location of the error can be found by looking at the nimbers in parentheeis after the error is called out. In this case we see (165,11). Which means the error was found in line 165 at character 11.  
  
As for thise of u that have the EA working in demo I recommend u use a copier that will copy the trades over to a live account. I have this setup on several EAs and have had no issues. Just make sure u set up lotsize and rosk properly.   
  
Good luck to all

A good trade copier is provided by fxblue. For those that are not familiar you need two expert advisors. A receiver and a sender.  
Place the sender EA on the account you want copied. For example in this case you place the receiver on a separate chart on the account that you are running your Candle Martingale EA. Then run the receiver EA on the account you want the trades to show up on. So I would open my live account and place on any chart the receiver EA.  
  
You can download the EAs at:  
fxblue.com/appstore/c6/trade-copying-apps  
  
You will see two options.  
The Personal Trade Copier is used when you are not sending your trade signals accross the internet. So if you are just on one machine you can use this.  
The Internet Mirror Copier is when you want to send your signals to any MT4 accross the internet.  
  
I recommend the personal cause you don't have to setup any signal subscribers and all the traffic is kept in one machine between one or as many accounts you want to link up to it.  
  
Read the Guides for more information on lotsize, balance protections, time filters. But u can just try the default values.. They should be ok.  
  
Good luck ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f600.png?v=15.1)
